teaching positions

2016 - present University of Salford Position: Lecturer in English Langugae & Salford Institute of Dementia Creativity Theme lead
2015 - 2016 York St John University Postion: Lecturer & Seminar Tutor
2014 - 2016 University of Leeds Postion: Lecturer & Seminar Tutor (MA and BA)

education

2012 - 2016 PhD, Department of Linguistics and Phonetics University of Leeds, Leeds Thesis: “What co-speech gestures do: investigating the communicative role of visual behaviour accompanying language use during reference in interaction” Supervisors: Dr Bethan Davies & Dr Catherine Davies
2010 - 2011 Master of Arts with Distinction in Pragmatics University College London, London Dissertation: “Contextual Substitutes: Exploring the role of gestural sequences during interaction” Supervisor: Professor Robyn Carston
2007-2010 Bachelor of Arts (First Class, Hons) in English Language and Linguistics York St John University, York Dissertation Title: “Doing being good: Face conflict and the co-construction of identity within an online Christian Community” Dissertation Supervisor: Dr Andrew Merrison

research positions

2019–present Associate Editor for the IPrA Bibliography of Pragmatics online
2014–2016 LPRG Institutionalised Impoliteness Research Assistant (Grade 5) Research Team: Linguistics Politeness Research Group (LPRG)
2010–2011 British Sign Language (BSL) Map Task Project Research Assistant (Grade 5) Research Team: Graham H. Turner (Heriot-Watt University), Andrew J. Merrison (York St. John University), Bethan L. Davies (University of Leeds), Gary Quinn (Heriot-Watt University) and Kyra Pollit (The Pollit Bureau, Edinburgh) Contact: Prof. Graham H. Turner

additional experience

2013–2016 Language at Leeds (L@L) PGR representative. I am the postgraduate student representative for the University of Leeds initiative, Language at Leeds. The aim L@L is to bring together researchers whose research focusses on Language. As part of my role I help organise a fornightly postgraduate seminar and workshops tailored towards the specific needs of our PGR community. I also help run and edit the Leeds working papers in linguistics and phonetics. In addition to these duties, in 2014 I helped organise an international conference addressing Multimodality.
2011–2013 Clark SOL. These supported open learning sessions were organised as part of a second year undergraduate linguistics module at York St John University. As part of the module students are required to read Herbert Clark’s (1996) textbook, Using Language. My role was to create an environment in which students could engage in discussion regarding the text.

This website is a personal space for me to share my work in linguisitcs, pragmatics and gesture studies. It is also a blog for sharing partially formed ideas. Criticisms are welcome!
